comment.author: 77186030@N00
comment._content:
Wow!  That looks to me like Trim, Meath.  Trim Castle and the Yellow Steeple in the background.

I know that bridge and now it's away from the river on the public foothpath.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: That's Trim alright.

comment.author: 77186030@N00
comment._content: Here's where the bridge is now. maps.google.com/maps?q=Trim,+Ireland&hl=en&ll=53....

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gregcarey] Trying to be delighted you got it so quickly!  :D

Does all of the structure of the bridge still survive? And tell us about the Yellow Steeple? That's a great name.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: From the angle it's taken from, it must be at the ruined church on the east side of the town.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gregcarey] I thought it was here: maps.google.com/maps?q=Trim,+Ireland&hl=en&ll=53....

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The yellow tower is the tower of St Mary's Abbey. Like most "yellow" places (e.g. yellow walls in Malahide), I think it's just named after the limestone used to build it. Maybe wikipedia will know.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: "the ruin of the abbey bell tower named for the yellow color reflected by the stonework in the setting sun"

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I climbed to the top of it once when I was about 9 or 10. It's quite high.

comment.author: 77186030@N00
comment._content: This is the only pic I could find on the web of where I think the bridge is located. i.ytimg.com/vi/J6KnmcoMykM/0.jpg (top left) I'll try to get a photo of the bridge as it is now over the weekend.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Here's a Google Streetview of the bridge now taken from the ring road maps.google.com/maps?q=Trim,+Ireland&hl=en&ll=53.... There used to be a channel of the river running through here which shows up on the old OS Maps but must have been filled in in the last century maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,680521,756536,7,9

comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: The 180 degree streetview really shows the view on the origial photo maps.google.com/maps?q=Trim,+Ireland&hl=en&ll=53....

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: The bridge to nowhere, another interesting picture NLI, I love it!

comment.author: 77186030@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] yes, you're right!  that's the bridge.

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: I've often walked past that piece of bridge.  I never realised the river used to run under it!

comment.author: 16941881@N00
comment._content: is it possible that the kids are orphans?? and that the well dressed ladies have taken them out for a day.... perhaps the guy in the uniform is there to make sure they don't run away???  just a thought.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mogey] Thanks for the location! Really weird to see a bridge just sitting in the middle of a field...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/franmoll] Anything is possible, but I think it was probably far less sinister.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: It looks like this could have been a mill race rather than a branch of the river. The old 6" map shows that in 1836 there was a Tuck Mill further downstream. Tuck Mills were associated with the woolen industry. 1836 Map maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,680784,756550,7,7

comment.author: 77186030@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Very interesting. But do you see the weir/inlet and the start of it there's a small bridge. I think this is the same bridge they're sitting on here.  But today that inlet is not there any more.

comment.author: 37424391@N07
comment._content: Respect,.!!

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gregcarey] that's right - if you use the overlay tool in OS Maps you can see it corresponds to the bridge as it is today (more or less)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gregcarey] A mill-race for sure, though possibly for an earlier mill near or on this bridge, if you look at the water flow on the old maps. When the weir shown downstream was taken away this section of the river Boyne would have silted and dried up. Thinking haymaking (see haystacks note). There is a Trim Haymaking Festival - Scurlogstown Olympiad at this very site nowadays. They would be fascinated to see this photo.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Great job - 10 minutes!  Is that a Record?

I thought they were supposed to be hard this week.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] No. I still have it with St Doulagh's. I think records should only count for fastest research though. If either Greg or I had seen this sooner we'd have broken the record, so it's really just about how fast you can spot that there's a new picture. Things like dating the Oscar Traynor pic were (to my mind) far more impressive.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] It's very big for a mill race, but I can't see what else it could be. It's not navigable with that weir across it.

comment.author: 77186030@N00
comment._content: Here's how it looks today: www.flickr.com/photos/gregcarey/8127420168/in/photostream

comment.author: 36519414@N00
comment._content: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Bridge_over_untroubled_wa...

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: In the older OS Map it looks like the channel is much narrower and the bridge spans across it. In the later map it is wider and looks more like what we're seeing in this photo. The area is prone to flooding which may have caused the widening of the mill race but the weir must then have been added to help waterflow for the mill.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Perhaps flooding caused the damage to the bridge

comment.author: 73932893@N00
comment._content: Anyone who has ever taken kids down near the water would tell you that the first thing you have to tell them, after "Stay out of the water!" is "Then at least take off your shoes!"
